snippet: LEAD: Feminist literary studies are a new thing on campuses, but they did not spring full-grown from the heads of the recent polemical feminists. For generations, well-read women have developed a chain of favorite authors, passed on by word-of-mou...
lead_paragraph: LEAD: Feminist literary studies are a new thing on campuses, but they did not spring full-grown from the heads of the recent polemical feminists. For generations, well-read women have developed a chain of favorite authors, passed on by word-of-mouth. My mother was my link to the feminist literary past. She introduced me to such important and then neglected authors as Olive Schreiner, Elizabeth Gaskell and Maria Edgeworth.

snippet: I was struck by the irony of the author declaring herself a feminist, yet announcing that having a "crush" on a male student not only has made her a better person (defined as someone who devotes more care to looking "terrific all the time") but al...
lead_paragraph: I was struck by the irony of the author declaring herself a feminist, yet announcing that having a "crush" on a male student not only has made her a better person (defined as someone who devotes more care to looking "terrific all the time") but also has made her a better teacher (by encouraging her to pay more attention to her female students now that they have become her sexual "rivals.") Welcome to the world of post-feminist feminism, where women grow "more animated" and "healthier" when they are mooning over men and learn to notice and appreciate other women in a professional setting only as their competitors for male favor, as collections of "firm curves, smooth skin, shiny hair."

headline.main: LOVE AND LEARN

snippet: To the Editor:    Stephen Holden was right in ''Chin Up, Cinderella, There's Still Hope'' [Jan. 26] that the television series ''Sex and the City'' is not a mainstream narrative of women's sexuality, particularly compared with blockbuster Hollywoo...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Stephen Holden was right in ''Chin Up, Cinderella, There's Still Hope'' [Jan. 26] that the television series ''Sex and the City'' is not a mainstream narrative of women's sexuality, particularly compared with blockbuster Hollywood films. Yet I remain unconvinced that the show's agenda is post-feminist. It sits squarely in the feminist tradition in its characters' repudiation of the sexual double standard and its valorization of female friendship.
abstract: Greta Gilbertson letter says TV series Sex and the City is in feminist tradition because its characters repudiate sexual double standard and value female friendship (S)

snippet: Much praise to Kristal Brent Zook for "A Manifesto of Sorts for a Black Feminist Movement" (Nov. 12).         Upon reading her article I heard the echo of my own voice calling beyond the  wilderness. Zook's discourse brought back for me the legacy...
lead_paragraph: Much praise to Kristal Brent Zook for "A Manifesto of Sorts for a Black Feminist Movement" (Nov. 12). Upon reading her article I heard the echo of my own voice calling beyond the wilderness. Zook's discourse brought back for me the legacy of the feminist author Maria Miller-Stewart. Stewart spoke to issues of black male responsibility, the same issues Louis Farrakhan presents as newly defined. Perhaps if men, both African-American and European-American, had listened to her voice 167 years ago, the Million Man March would not have been a necessity.

headline.main: A MANIFESTO OF SORTS FOR A BLACK FEMINIST MOVEMENT

snippet: To the Editor:   In "Down the Aisle, Surprised" (Op-Ed, Oct. 24), Amy Gelman describes her apparently traditional yet feminist wedding. She mentions some phenomena associated with a traditional wedding -- a long white wedding dress, 100 guests, a ...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In "Down the Aisle, Surprised" (Op-Ed, Oct. 24), Amy Gelman describes her apparently traditional yet feminist wedding. She mentions some phenomena associated with a traditional wedding -- a long white wedding dress, 100 guests, a typical mother of the bride who had been planning the wedding "since the day I was born" -- but something seems to be missing. I don't mean words of male domination like love; I mean what at traditional weddings is the object of the bride's love, the bridegroom. Ms. Gelman makes no mention of the bridegroom. For a moment, I thought this was the ideal feminist wedding, but Ms. Gelman uses the word traditional, and traditional weddings require a live, mobile male body to walk next to the bride. So I concluded that there indeed was a bridegroom at her wedding, but one relegated to semi-personhood, about as important to the wedding as the waiters, but less than the caterer. Ms. Gelman is generationally evenhanded. She doesn't mention her father either. That is in keeping with her description of her mother as "a feminist since long before anyone used that word." JOSEPH ADAMS Hillsdale, N. J., Oct. 27, 1990

headline.main: What's Missing From This Wedding?

snippet: THE NEW FEMINIST CRITICISM Essays on Women, Literature, and Theory. Edited by Elaine Showalter. 403 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.   DURING the last decade, the influence of feminist literary theory and criticism has dramatically increased,...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW FEMINIST CRITICISM Essays on Women, Literature, and Theory. Edited by Elaine Showalter. 403 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95. DURING the last decade, the influence of feminist literary theory and criticism has dramatically increased, not only changing the shape of literary studies but also substantially affecting work in other fields that are concerned with the definition of interpretive strategies. Because many significant essays first published in feminist and academic journals have not been widely available, there is cause to celebrate the publication of ''The New Feminist Criticism: Essays on Women, Literature, and Theory'' edited by Elaine Showalter, one of its earliest exponents. The 18 essays here are important both in defining many areas of concern and disagreement that have chiefly occupied feminist critics in recent years and in suggesting some strengths and weaknesses of one of the primary theoretical approaches to have emerged.

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Though I grant that most women leaders in Asia achieved power through male relatives, your Nov. 10 Week in Review appraisal is parsimonious. Under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, India joined the nuclear fraternity and nationalized the banks. In Bangladesh, Prime Minister Hazina Wazed has restored democratic institutions. Tamil violence has not escalated under President Chandrika Kumaratunga of Sri Lanka.
abstract: Nita Shah letter on female leaders of Asia (S)

headline.main: Women Who Lead

snippet: What Betty Friedan has failed to recognize is not only the need ''to free ourselves from the male power traps,'' but from the female power traps as well. Many feminists have become so fanatical in maintaining or furthering their already hard-earne...
lead_paragraph: What Betty Friedan has failed to recognize is not only the need ''to free ourselves from the male power traps,'' but from the female power traps as well. Many feminists have become so fanatical in maintaining or furthering their already hard-earned positions that they've discouraged the ambitions and perseverance of other women, seeing them not as co-feminists, but as a collective threat to their power. While one would undoubtedly encounter the same competitive obstacles in a male-dominated work force, the irony here exists specifically when it is the feminist herself who denies support to her qualified sisters. DEBORAH E. ANDERS, Fairport, N.Y.

snippet: Many thanks to Hochschild for saying publicly what many of us have admitted privately for years: that work outside the home pays more, has more status and is far easier than raising children. The question remains: Does that mean it's better?    Th...
lead_paragraph: Many thanks to Hochschild for saying publicly what many of us have admitted privately for years: that work outside the home pays more, has more status and is far easier than raising children. The question remains: Does that mean it's better? The feminist revolution will not be complete until the ''female'' world of home and children is valued as highly as the ''male'' world of work. Ellen Donohue Warwick Arlington, Mass.
abstract: Ellen Donohue Warwick letter praises April 20 article for saying what many people admit privately: that work outside the home pays more and is far easier than raising children (S)

Based on a quick survey, he concluded that the unnamed book ''appears to make a good deal of disturbing sense.'' The name of the book is ''The Sexual Politics of Meat,'' and I am its author. Carol J. Adams Richardson, Tex.

snippet: It's true that Prince Charles might qualify as a new romantic hero, a feminist one at that. After all, he prefers brains to beauty and age to youth. He also seems to be a one-woman man. What a reversal of centuries of male tradition. But our Emma ...
lead_paragraph: It's true that Prince Charles might qualify as a new romantic hero, a feminist one at that. After all, he prefers brains to beauty and age to youth. He also seems to be a one-woman man. What a reversal of centuries of male tradition. But our Emma Bovary? Give me a break. A major difference between Charles and that touchstone heroine is that his adulterous love was reciprocated. Elaine Hoffman Baruch New York

snippet: The opinion expressed in ''A Disastrous Loss for Feminists'' [Oct. 19] speaks to the heart of why the feminist movement, as political ideologue, fails. If the person in question was male, this action of choosing family over business would have bee...
lead_paragraph: The opinion expressed in ''A Disastrous Loss for Feminists'' [Oct. 19] speaks to the heart of why the feminist movement, as political ideologue, fails. If the person in question was male, this action of choosing family over business would have been lauded. The emphasis on gender, rather than role and value choice, lets us know how far we have not come. To have praised Ms. Barnes for her decision would have supported her right to make a choice.
abstract: Letter by Suzanne Hogan on Rosalie Osias's Oct 19 article on Brenda Barnes's decision to resign as president and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola Co North America to spend more time with her family; says Osias's opinion speaks to heart of why feminist movement, as political ideologue, fails; adds if the person in question was male, this action of choosing family over business would have been lauded (S)

headline.main: Feminism's Failure As Political Ideologue

snippet: To the Editor:    Charlotte St. Martin is an admirable woman, having worked her way up from being a movie theater concessionaire to executive vice presient for marketing of Loews Hotels (''Cheers for Work! Rah! Rah!,'' Business Day, March 1). Howe...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Charlotte St. Martin is an admirable woman, having worked her way up from being a movie theater concessionaire to executive vice presient for marketing of Loews Hotels (''Cheers for Work! Rah! Rah!,'' Business Day, March 1). However, she gives feminism a bad name when she says she is not a feminist because she did not ask why men were holding her back.
abstract: Jody Ratner letter on March 1 profile in which Loews Hotel executive Charlotte St Martin says she is not a feminist and rose through ranks because she worked 'harder'; points out that her efforts make her an advocate of equal rights for women, in other words, a feminist (S)

headline.main: Undercover Feminist

snippet: RUSH--Florence, author of The Best Kept Secret, published in 1980, and the first feminist theorist to call the sexual abuse of children a political and patriarchal issue, died on Tuesday, December 9, at her home in Manhattan, just short of her 91s...
lead_paragraph: RUSH--Florence, author of The Best Kept Secret, published in 1980, and the first feminist theorist to call the sexual abuse of children a political and patriarchal issue, died on Tuesday, December 9, at her home in Manhattan, just short of her 91st birthday. Married with three children she moved from the Bronx to Westchester where she worked as a psychiatric social worker and a community activist in the civil rights movement. After moving to Greenwich Village she electrified a New York Radical Feminist Conference on Rape in 1971 with her theory which identified male relatives and family friends as the major sexual abusers of children. When her son, Matthew, contracted AIDS, she formed a mothers' support group. She worked with Women Against Pornography and NOW to oppose exploitation of children in the media. For many years Florence enjoyed a weekly poker game with neighbors and friends who warmly recall her gracious hospitality in New York and Fire Island, and will never forget her original mind, her singular contribution to feminist theory, her impossible platform shoes, and her lasagna. She is survived by her son, Thomas, her daughter, Eleanor, and two grandchildren. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  Rush, Florence

lead_paragraph: RUSH--Florence, author of The Best Kept Secret, published in 1980, and the first feminist theorist to call the sexual abuse of children a political and patriarchal issue, died on Tuesday, December 9, at her home in Manhattan, just short of her 91st birthday. Married with three children she moved from the Bronx to Westchester where she worked as a psychiatric social worker and a community activist in the civil rights movement. After moving to Greenwich Village she electrified a New York Radical Feminist Conference on Rape in 1971 with her theory which identified male relatives and family friends as the major sexual abusers of children. When her son, Matthew, contracted AIDS, she formed a mothers' support group. She worked with Women Against Pornography and NOW to oppose exploitation of children in the media. For many years Florence enjoyed a weekly poker game with neighbors and friends who warmly recall her gracious hospitality in New York and Fire Island, and will never forget her original mind, her singular contribution to feminist theory, her impossible platform shoes, and her lasagna. headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSH, FLORENCE

snippet: To the Editor:    In her review of Susan Griffin's ''Pornography and Silence'' and Andrea Dworkin's ''Pornography: Men Possessing Women'' (July 12), Ellen Willis links both authors and the feminist anti-pornography movement to the conservative, fu...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In her review of Susan Griffin's ''Pornography and Silence'' and Andrea Dworkin's ''Pornography: Men Possessing Women'' (July 12), Ellen Willis links both authors and the feminist anti-pornography movement to the conservative, fundamentalist backlash. Yet Ellen Willis fails to offer any evidence in support of such a connection, except to intimate that it is suspicious that both movements are opposed to pornography and both have emerged at the same time. A crucial fact that Ellen Willis chooses to ignore is that feminist objections to pornography are the antithesis of those of the Moral Majority. Feminist opposition to pornography is founded on the belief that pornography is a powerful agent of socialization that shapes human sexuality in such a way as to bolster male dominance and female subservience. As long as men are taught that female bodies are objects of conquest and possession, feminists argue, sexual crimes, from harassment to rape, and a cultural devaluation of women will prevail. In striking contrast, fundamentalists are against pornography because they believe that female bodies and female sexuality are evil and corrupting, the true legacy of Eve. Moreover, the Moral Majority can afford to oppose pornography because, unlike other male-dominated movements, it does not need pornography in order to keep women devalued and subservient - it has the Bible and the traditional family for that.

snippet: The world has previously seen what transpired at the Knitting Factory on Thursday: fiery women dressed in fashionable tatters creating art pieces about propriety and desire only to rip the work, and almost themselves, to shreds.    It might have b...
lead_paragraph: The world has previously seen what transpired at the Knitting Factory on Thursday: fiery women dressed in fashionable tatters creating art pieces about propriety and desire only to rip the work, and almost themselves, to shreds. It might have been a Dada show in Berlin between the wars or a Yoko Ono happening in swinging London. But this was the new trio Chicks on Speed, rekindling the eternal spark of feminist enlightenment.

snippet: To the Editor:   Mark Twain would probably disagree with Germaine Greer's comment about the sexual advantages possessed by silver-haired men. He lamented a man's loss of ability while envying a woman's continued sexual competence: "After 50 his pe...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Mark Twain would probably disagree with Germaine Greer's comment about the sexual advantages possessed by silver-haired men. He lamented a man's loss of ability while envying a woman's continued sexual competence: "After 50 his performance is of poor quality, the intervals between are wide, and its satisfactions of no great value to either party." In suggesting that women's sexual pleasures with male partners are dependent on nubile breasts or silicone implants or youth, Ms. Greer seems to have ignored much feminist writing. Post-menopausal women can and do enjoy sex with men. LAURA B. MAIER Walla Walla, Wash.

headline.main: 'The Change'

snippet: As an American, I have no great interest in the British royal succession. As a feminist, however, I am outraged by speculation that Queen Elizabeth should abdicate to make way for the restless Prince Charles. Can you imagine anyone suggesting that...
lead_paragraph: As an American, I have no great interest in the British royal succession. As a feminist, however, I am outraged by speculation that Queen Elizabeth should abdicate to make way for the restless Prince Charles. Can you imagine anyone suggesting that a male sovereign in perfectly good health retire at the age of 65? Perhaps there is a fear that Charles might fall prey to the fate Edward VII did, while waiting for his mother, Queen Victoria, to die. Surely, this says more about the character of British manhood than about the legitimate right of the Queen to live out her reign as any other sovereign would. SUSAN KAUFMAN Great Barrington, Mass.

snippet: To the Editor:     I am a young female-to-male transsexual and an active part of feminist, lesbian and queer community. My biggest problem is not sex-change troubles, nor the lesbians who don't accept me. My biggest problem is transphobic and hete...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am a young female-to-male transsexual and an active part of feminist, lesbian and queer community. My biggest problem is not sex-change troubles, nor the lesbians who don't accept me. My biggest problem is transphobic and heterosexist attitudes in the mainstream world, where just as in your article everything about my life is seen as sensational and slightly tragic.
abstract: Sailor Lewis Wallace letter says her biggest problem as an active feminist and lesbian is transphobic and heterosexist attidues in mainstrem world, where just as in Aug 20 article on female-to-male transsexuals everything about her life is seen as sensational and slightly tragic

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Anita F. abstract: Emboldened by the Egyptian revolution to claim a new voice in public life, many Egyptian women are finding that they are still dependent on the protection of men; Egyptian feminists had hoped for far greater power following the heady days of the revolution, when they played an active and equal role in bringing down a dictator.
